newsitem.title: LATVIA: Balt presidents plan meet Ukraine, Polish leaders.
newsitem.headline: Balt presidents plan meet Ukraine, Polish leaders.

text.p: The Baltic presidents have invited Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma and Poland's Aleksander Kwasniewski to a meeting to be held on the day Russia and NATO plan to sign a new partnership deal, officials said on Tuesday.
But they stressed the timing was a coincidence and that the meeting would talk only generally of security issues.
"The meeting is to look at our cooperation, what the situation is now and how we can promote it," an Estonian Foreign Ministry official told Reuters.
Estonian President Lennart Meri is this year hosting the annual meeting with Latvian President Guntis Ulmanis and Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas on May 26 and 27.
NATO and Russia plan to sign a deal on May 27 in Paris to forge a new partnership and calm Russian fears over NATO growth.
Kuchma has confirmed he will meet his Baltic counterparts on May 27 while a reply from Kwasniewski is expected this week.
The Baltic states, independent from the former Soviet Union since 1991 and still wary of Russia, all want NATO membership.
But it is likely they will not get into the alliance in a first round of expansion as Moscow is against their inclusion.
Poland seems certain to be asked to join NATO at a summit in Madrid in July while Ukraine does not want to join NATO but is hoping for a special agreement with the alliance.
Unlike Russia, Ukraine does not oppose NATO's planned eastward March.
Baltic diplomats said the May meeting was not being held to demonstrate eastern European solidarity in the face of Russian hostility to NATO's expansion.
"We would not consider backing that idea, there is no reason to create that kind of regional group," a senior Lithuanian official said.
